title: An X-HTDC method for estimating particulate phosphorus from microalgae
title_html: An X-HTDC method for estimating particulate phosphorus from microalgae

protocol.title: An X-HTDC method for estimating particulate phosphorus from microalgae

source.description: Sampling microalgae for total particulate phosphorus (i.e. intracellular phosphorus and adsorbed phosphorus)
Filter microalgae in liquid media onto polycarbonate filters, using gentle vacuum pressure (5 inches Hg).
Rinse samples with filtered seawater
Place sample filters in 2 mL Cryogenic Vials.
Filter blank media (without cells) through polycarbonate filter as blank.

Flash freeze filters and store at
.
Sampling microalgae for intracellular particulate phosphorus
Filter microalgae in liquid media onto polycarbonate filters , using gentle vacuum pressure (5 inches Hg).

Add
oxalate reagent onto the filter, and let oxalate reagent sit in the filter funnel for

source.title: Preparation of oxalate reagent
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"7qma2","text":"This protocol describes how to prepare oxalate reagent, which is used to remove surface adsorbed phosphorus, so that the intracellular phosphorus quotas in microalgae can be measured.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bdpo3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f66dv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"7uiqo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"citation","data":{"authors":"AntonioTovar-Sanchez, Sergio A Sa\u00f1udo-Wilhelmy, Manuel Garcia-Vargas, Richard S Weaver, Linda C Popels, David A Hutchins","can_edit":1,"date":null,"doi":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1016\/S0304-4203(03)00054-9","guid":"01891C70B0BA11EAA89EE71FB0FFEF12","id":500,"journal":"Marine Chemistry","protocol_id":null,"title":"A trace metal clean reagent to remove surface-bound iron from marine phytoplankton"}}]}
Drain and then rinse the sample with filtered seawater once
Place sample filters in 2 mL Cryogenic Vials.
Filter blank media (without cells) through polycarbonate filter as blank.

Flash freeze filters and store at
.

Mark number at the bottom of each crucible with pencil, log the following information:
(1) The number of crucible
(2) The code of sample in the crucible
Transfer sample to crucible with clean filter forceps.

MgSO4 reagent:
Dissolve
MgSO4 in 50 mL MilliQ water

Add
MgSO­4 to each sample and blank filter.

Partly cover the crucibles and place in the oven at
until samples are completely dry.

Combust dried samples at
for

source.body: Map the location of crucibles in the oven, in case pencil mark disappears under 800°C.

Ramp rate should be controlled at < /hour or follow the instruction provided by manufacture, otherwise the crucibles might shatter.
SP.RAT: 150/PAMPU: hour
Or
SP.RAT: 2.5/PAMPU: minute

source.description: Allow samples to gradually cool down in the muffle furnace.
Pencil mark on crucibles should be still visible, however, it can be easily removed by water. Therefore, when removing samples out of the furnace, label the lid and crucible with sharpie immediately.

HCl reagent:
In a reagent bottle, dissolve one part of
HCl in 59 parts of MilliQ water
Preheat oven to
Add 2.5 mL 0.2 M HCl to each crucible.
Gently swirl the crucible.
Cover the crucibles and place crucibles in the oven for
Cool samples down to
Gently swirl the crucible and then transfer 500 ul solution to 2 mL microtube. Duplicate each sample and blank.
Standard working solutions and reagents can be prepared during sample digestion.
KH2PO4 primary standard stock solution (≈ 1 mM)
Transfer about 1 g KH2PO4 into a beaker, cover the beaker with foil

Place the beaker into an oven, dry KH2PO4 at
for at least
Move KH2PO4 into a vacuum desiccator, allow KH2PO4 to cool to room temperature

Dissolve around 0.136 g dried KH2PO4 in 1 L milliQ water.
  • Use 1 L volumetric flask
  • Take notes of the actual weight of KH2PO4 for final concentration of standard stock solution
Transfer standard stock solution into a 1 L bottle and store in the fridge.

source.body: This stock solution lasts quite a long time, unless there is evidence for growth of algae or other extraneous biotic material.

ammonium molybdate reagent:

ammonium molybdate in a Falcon tube and top to
with MilliQ water.
Cap and shake until totally dissolved.

with MilliQ water;
Cap and shake until all dissolved.

source.body: Wrap the tube with foil if the reagent is not used right after prepared.

Subtract the average absorbance at 820 nm of the blank standard replicates from the absorbance at 820 nm of all other standard working solutions.
Subtract the average absorbance at 820 nm of the blank sample (i.e. blank filter) replicates from the absorbance at 820 nm of all other individual samples.
Prepare a standard curve by plotting the average blank-corrected 820 nm absorbance for each standard working solution versus its concentration in uM.
Use the standard curve to determine the orthophosphate concentration of each unknown sample by using its blank-corrected 820 nm absorbance.
(P per sample)_ug = (orthophosphate)_uM X (V_HCl)_mL X (0.001) X (30.97)

source.body: All reagents are freshly prepared before colorimetric measurement.

description:
Here we describe a protocol to estimate particulate phosphorus associated with microalgae using an extra-high temperature dry combustion method (X-HTDC). An 800°C-combustion can completely decompose intracellular macromolecules, improving estimates of particulate phosphorus relative to methods that use lower combustion temperatures. Based on tests on Prorocentrum triestinum in exponential growth in f/2 medium, estimates of intracellular particulate phosphorus are increased by 10% compared with the traditional 500 °C combustion method.
We recommend microalgae be collected on polycarbonate filters and then combusted at 800 °C before digestion by 0.2 M HCl for 30 minutes at 90°C. The resulting orthophosphate is detected by mixing the digested sample with a mixture of molybdate and ascorbic acid to produce molybdenum blue (Chen 1956).
The working range of this assay is 0 to 200 uM orthophosphate; and the recommended maximum phosphorus per sample filter is about 30 ug.
In order to assess the intracellular phosphorus in microalgae, we recommend an oxalate reagent (Tovar-Sanchez 2003) to wash the microalgae collected on the filter to remove surface adsorbed phosphorus.
